awd_titl_txt: Enhancing the Transfer Experience through a Collaborative Cohort Program for Engineering Scholars
awd_abstract_narration:
This five-year project aims to contribute to the national need for well-educated engineers.  It will support the success of at least thirty low-income, high-achieving STEM undergraduate students with demonstrated financial need at Fresno City College, a two-year institution. Specifically, the project will provide two-year scholarships to five cohorts of students who are pursuing an associate's degree or certificate in engineering at Fresno City College. At least thirty students will be supported at Fresno City College, two of whom will receive an additional two-year scholarship to complete a bachelor's degree in engineering at California State-Fresno.  At Fresno City College, the Scholars will participate in program orientation at the beginning of each fall semester, pursue a transfer pathway curriculum designed to transition students to a four-year university engineering program, attend bi-weekly seminar events and monthly meetings with faculty mentors and peer mentors, serve as peer mentors for succeeding cohorts of Scholars, and participate in undergraduate research projects in collaboration with California State-Fresno. Fresno City College is a Hispanic-serving institution and recruiting will focus on women and students with disabilities, thus increasing the potential of the project to broaden participation in engineering. 


The goal of the project is to increase degree completion of low-income, high-achieving engineering undergraduates. The project includes a research plan to determine factors that influence student identity and sense of belonging. The researchers will test the hypothesis that engaging Fresno City College students in a collaborative, cohort experience will support students' movement from the periphery of learning to the center of a community in which learning is a collective experience guided by community membership. This project has the potential to create new knowledge about how the socio-cultural context of students from an area of concentrated poverty, such as Fresno, experience community and develop a STEM identity.  This project is funded by the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, which seeks to increase the number of low-income, academically high-achieving students with demonstrated financial need who earn degrees in STEM fields. It also aims to improve the education of future scientists, engineers, and technicians, and to generate knowledge about academic success, retention, transfer, graduation, and academic/career pathways of low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Engineering Scholars Program (ESP) at Fresno City College (FCC) made significant strides in its mission to foster a diverse and inclusive STEM community, increase participation in engineering among economically disadvantaged students, and establish collaborative transfer support processes between FCC and California State University-Fresno Lyles College of Engineering. The ESP awarded a total of 131 semester-long scholarships from 2019 to 2024, providing financial support to students majoring in engineering. In addition to scholarships, the program offered academic advising, professional development through academic seminars and events, undergraduate research, faculty mentoring, and peer mentoring.  

The program’s intellectual merit was assessed through research questions exploring how participation in a collaborative cohort contributes to students’ membership within a STEM community and how students use community membership to construct their own STEM identity. The research revealed that the ESP played a significant role in nurturing students’ STEM identity and fostering a sense of community, highlighted by improving in scholars’ academic performance, with many reporting higher GPAs and increased engagement in their coursework; helping students develop a strong STEM identity, which is crucial for persistence in the field; providing undergraduate research opportunities, allowing students to engage in hands-on learning and contribute to the body of knowledge within the engineering discipline; faculty mentorship that pivotal role in the program, offering guidance and support to students, which enhanced the educational experience and contributed to the intellectual rigor of the program; forming a community for scholars through peer mentoring, which supported scholars’ transfer process by providing connections that proved to be essential when preparing to transfer and settling into a new institution; and fostering a collaborative learning environment where students could work together, share knowledge, and support each other’s academic endeavors. The program has not only enhanced the academic success of its participants but also contributed to the broader goal of diversifying the engineering field. 

The ESP’s broader impacts are evident in its contribution to society. The program catered to a substantial number of students from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds, providing them with the support and resources necessary to pursue their engineering degrees and transfer to four-year universities. Some key areas where the program has made a significant impact include: promoting diversity within the STEM fields; empowering individuals and their families economically by providing scholarships and financial support; contributing to the development of a skilled workforce in engineering, aligning with national goals; creating clear pathways for students to continue their education; providing opportunities for scholars to contribute to the advancement of engineering knowledge. Overall, the ESP exemplified the transformative power of inclusive education and mentorship in shaping the future of STEM industries. 

The program also achieved its specific objectives of increasing engineering degree completion rates at FCC, reducing the average time to degree, and increasing 2-year engineering transfer rates from FCC to four-year institutions.  The ESP aimed to increase engineering degree and/or certificate completion rates at FCC to 5% over the project timeline. While the full impact of this objective will not be determinable until after the project concludes, early results indicate that the percentage of students majoring in engineering at FCC completing degrees within 2 years only observed incremental changes. The ESP aimed to reduce the average time to degree for engineering at FCC from 10.4 semesters to 8 semesters over the project timeline. This objective was successfully accomplished. The ESP aimed to increase 2-year engineering transfer rates from FCC to four-year institutions from 7.7% to 10%. However, early results indicate that the percentage of students majoring in engineering at FCC transferring within 2 years did not improve as expected during the project timeline. 

The ESP made significant strides in fostering a diverse and inclusive STEM community, increasing participation in engineering among economically disadvantaged students, and establishing collaborative transfer support processes. The program’s success serves as a testament to the power of community, mentorship, and targeted support in promoting STEM education and career pathways. The ESP’s success also underscores the importance of maintaining program components that have proven effective, such as faculty mentorship, opportunities for exploration within the engineering field, and links to alumni. The cooperative efforts between departments with shared goals at both FCC and CSU-F are poised to continue addressing the needs of scholars from the two-year college to the transfer university by providing these impactful experiences well into the future.  


Last Modified: 08/02/2024
Modified by: Nihal Orfi
